title: Do Solar Panels Work in Winter in the UK?

data.author: EvoHome Team
data.excerpt: Short answer: yes. Solar still generates on cold and cloudy days — here’s how to size your system and what output to expect.
data.body:
Winter output vs summer

UK PV systems generate less in winter due to shorter days and lower sun angles, but cold panels are actually more efficient. A well-specified array with south or south-west orientation still provides meaningful energy.

How to size

  • Use at least 3.5–5 kWp for typical homes
  • Add battery storage to capture brief winter peaks
  • Optimise with microinverters or optimisers if shading exists

Tariffs

Pair with off-peak EV/heat pump tariffs to shift loads and maximise savings.

title: Air Source Heat Pump Running Costs Explained

data.author: EvoHome Team
data.excerpt: We break down COP, tariffs and real-world costs so you know what to expect on your bills.
data.body:
What affects cost?

Three things: your home’s heat loss, the pump’s seasonal COP (SCOP) and your electricity tariff.

Key tips

  • Lower flow temperatures increase efficiency
  • Use weather compensation controls
  • Consider off-peak tariffs

With good design, SCOP of 3.5–4.5 is achievable in UK homes.

title: Are Home Batteries Worth It in the UK?

data.author: EvoHome Team
data.excerpt: Batteries let you use solar at night and shift usage to cheap off-peak rates. Here’s the ROI math.
data.body:
When a battery pays back

If you have PV and evening usage, a 5–10 kWh battery often pays back in 5–9 years. Without PV, time-of-use (ToU) shifting can still work on EV/heat pump tariffs.

Right sizing

Match capacity to your evening kWh. Too small = frequent empty; too big = slow payback.

title: Best Window Options for UK Homes in 2025

data.author: EvoHome Team
data.excerpt: uPVC vs aluminium, double vs triple glazing, and what U-values actually mean.
data.body:
Frame materials

uPVC is cost-effective and insulating; aluminium offers slim sightlines and durability. Both can hit low U-values with the right spec.

Glazing

Modern double glazing with warm edge spacers and argon fill is often the sweet spot for cost/performance. Triple glazing helps in exposed or noisy locations.
